content.text: JavaScript Iterables

An Iterable is an Iterable Object
An iterable can be iterated over with for..of loops
The For Of Loop

The JavaScript for..of statement loops 
through the elements of an iterable object.
Iterating
Iterating means looping over a sequence of elements.
Here are some easy examples:

Iterating over a String
Iterating over an Array
Iterating over a Set
Iterating over a Map

Iterating Over a Map
You can use a for..of loop to iterate over the elements of a Map:
JavaScript Iterators
The iterator protocol defines how to produce a sequence of values from an object.
An object becomes an iterator when it implements a next() method.
The next() method must return an object with two properties:

value (the next value)
done (true or false)

data:
The value returned by the iterator
(Can be omitted if done is true)

true if the iterator has completed
false if the iterator has produced a new value

content.text:
Note
Technically, iterables must implement the Symbol.iterator method.
In JavaScript the following are iterables:

Strings
Arrays
Typed Arrays
Sets
Maps

Because their prototype objects have a
Symbol.iterator method:
Home Made Iterable

This iterable returns never ending number: 10,20,30,40,.... when  the
next() method is called:

Note
Home made iterables do not support the JavaScript for..of statement.
A JavaScript iterable is an object that has a Symbol.iterator.
The Symbol.iterator is a function that returns a next() function.
An iterable can be iterated over with the code: for (const x of iterable) { }
The Symbol.iterator method is called automatically by for..of.
But we can also do it "manually":

Note
Iterators provide a controlled way to work with data sequences,
enabling custom iteration logic for various data structures.
In the next chapter you will learn about the new Iterator Helper Functions introduced in ECMAScript 2025.
